62ND YEAR

Ike, Macmillan To View Graduation,
Speak To University AssemblyIn June

HAROLD MACMILLAN

British Prime Minister Harold 'Macmillan and Dwight
D. Eisenhower, President of the United States, will attend
the commencement exercises at Hopkins on Tuesday,
June 10.
White House Press Secretary James Haggerty also
announced that Macmillan will deliver the principal address at the ceremonies. Macmillan is scheduled to receive
an honorary degree from the University.
Macmillan will be in the United States to confer with
the President and other U.S. leaders.
The Prime Minister is expected to arrive in the
United States on June 7 and will first speak at graduation
exercises at DePaul University, in Greencastle, Indiana, his
mother's home state, on June 8.
The original invitation to Mr. Macmillan to address
the graduating Hopkins students was extended personally
by Dr. Milton Eisenhower, president of Hopkins and the
brother of the President. His acceptance was received at
the White House a week ago.
The Prime Minister, the son of an English father
and an American mother, accepted his ilost January 10,
1957, at a time when a rift was appearing between England
and the U.S. over the former's policy toward Egypt.
He is generally considered to have been a major force
in helping to repair Anglo-American relations.
Macmillan, a personal friend of the President since
1942, met Eisenhower as the British Cabinet's political representative at Eisenhower's wartime headquarters in Africa.
When Eden became Prime Minister in 1955, he named
Macmillan to succeed him as Secretary of State for Foreign
Affairs. Eight months later Macmillan took over England's
finances by becoming Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Macmillan will be making his fifth visit to the U.S.
in the past three years. His most recent appearance in
Washington last October led to a joint statement with
President Eisenhower of a "declaration of common purpose" between the United States and Britain.

Figinski, Turnbull Ascend `Gad-Fly' Pressman
To News-Letter Editorship Shifts, To Back Long

AL FIGINSKI

RUD TURNBULL

The editors of the News-Letter
for 1958-59 will be junior political science majors Al Figinski
and Rud Turnbull. Their Business Manager will be junior Ed
Smith.
At elections held Wednesday
night, news editor Cleave Miller
was elected managing editor;
and assistant news editor Niels
Sundermeyer was elected associate editor.
Sports editor Stan Handmaker
retained his position, while fresh-

men Harry Lambright and Dave
Baker assumed the jobs of news
and copy editors, respectively.
Assistant feature editor Pete
Kivic moved up to the editorship
of that department, while Bob
Franke was elevated to the Board
of Control as composition editor.
Freshman Gerry Spanier became photography editor and
will dub in as a features writer
also.

and Herb Kahler stated that

CLAY FLORIST

23 WEST CLAY STREET

Hyman Pressman, perennial
gad-fly of Senate candidate
Mayor Thomas D'Alesandro, this
week announced himself as a
supporter of Hopkins economist
Clarence D. Long, one of the
Mayor's rivals in a four-way,
no-holds-barred race for the
Democratic nomination.
Mr. Pressman said that Dr.
Long's "biggest obstacle" is
voter negativisril—an attitude
that Dr. Long will not be able to
win and thus the votes cast for
him are wasted.
"There is a question in the
minds of the voters whether he
can win. If they learn he can
win, they will vote for him ...
I am doing what I can to make
the people be convinced that
Long can win."
Many Voters For Long
, Mr. Pressman declared his
support Monday night, and on
Tuesday afternoon he said, "The
reaction of the people today
shows that many people will
vote for Long. The general public not affiliated with organized
ward politics will vote for Long,"
if, Mr. Pressman added, they
think he can win.
The Baltimore lawyer explained that "many people had
told me I ought to go on the
air the night before the election,
because my backing of Dr. Long
would carry weight ... But I
don't (now) plan to go on the
air . . Instead of waiting until
then, I have made known my
desires before then."
"The People's Choice"
He cited Dr. Long as being the
only one of the four major candidates who "is truly the
people's choice."

night he declared that "you

Second Talk In 'Y'Series
'Physiology Of Marriage'
"The Physiology of Marriage"
was the topic of a talk to be
given by Dr. Douglas Cariol of
the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
Wednesday, April 23, in the
Sherwood Room, Levering Hall,
at 6 p.m. A buffet supper preceded at 5:30 p.m.
The lecture is second part of
the YMCA "Marriage for Moderns" series which began earlier
in the year with Dr. Peter Bertocci's well-received "Human
venture: Love, Sex and Marriage." The third and concluding lecture of the series will be
given May 14 on "Sociological
Aspects of Marriage," the speaker to be announced later.

The Johns Hopkins Fund, designed to raise $76,380,000 to
assist in the development fund
recently announced by the University, has received great impetus with the announcement that
Gary Black, Baltimore newspaper executive, has been named
to head the committee for Special Gifts, with Harrison Garrett
serving as vice-chairman, while
Carlyle Barton, former president
of the board of trustees of the
Johns Hopkins University, will
serve as head of a committee of
and

Alumni.
The committee for Special
Gifts will direct its early efforts
toward four priority areas set up
by the 7und in the $76 million
drive. They are (1) construction
of a Children's Medical Center
at the Hospital, (2) funds for increased faculty salaries and
new areas of research and instruction, (3) construction of a
new library at Homewood and
(4) construction of a new
physics building at Homewood.

Valediction
This issue marks the final chapter in the book of
Baroway and Kahler. Next week Turnbull and Figinski
will assume the role of the household lords, and may the
gods that be go with them. We two have made some discoveries about this campus within the past year. For
one, history repeats itself: in perusing past News-Letters
and conversing with past editors we learned, and it was
no surprise, that as far back as the '20's editors were
feuding with the Student Council and various other student
organizations, dormitory food provoked riots, this paper
was looked upon as a scandal sheet, fraternity drinking
was then a problem, and everybody and his brother
looked upon campus dilemmas with severity and regarded
them as very important.
We have also discovered that these problems, which
may appear to us in later years to be but petty foibles,
should be important to us.now. As important as hydrogen
bombs, or recessions, or national politics. For this is our
little world, yours and ours. We live here. We feed upon
its fruits, and we die a thousand deaths when' some
monkey wrench gets flung into it.

--Correspondence
To the Editors!
We read with interest the
News-Letter article of April 18
about the enlargement of the
Student Council to include the
editor of the News-Letter and the
Cotillion Board President. Undoubtedly, the Student Council
Will be a more effective organization with these new representatives, and in the future there
Will be less conflict among campus organizations.
However, we were very sorry
to see that the enlargement
stopped where it did. It seems
to us that if the News-Letter
is represented, then WJHU, the
campus radio station, should be
also; if the Cotillion Board, then
the 'Y' Cabinet. The Engineering Control Board certainly deserves a place on the SC, but an
Arts and Sciences Control Board
and a Business Control Board
should be created to represent
these students too. Last year's
admission of the IFB President
Should be followed by the creation of an officer to represent
the GDI's, and perhaps the Baltimore students need a vote to
balance the DSRC's vote.
Since the Deans and Chairmen of all the departments will
find the new SC a perfect place
for dealing with the student
body, they also should be voted
to membership. In fact, there is
no reason why anybody should
be excluded from the Student
Council.
Joseph H. Condon
Theodore W. Palmer

don't believe that it is necessary

The IFB, SAC, HC, and DSRC

Pirates Hang 'Jolly Roger'
From University Mainmast
A black flag, described by observers as a "Jolly Roger," was
removed from the flagpole near
Homewood House with considerable difficulty. A crew from the
Plant Manager's Office produced
one intrepid volunteer who, after
several slips and false starts,
succeeded in removing the object.
An unidentified secretary attempted to wrest the flag from
the man who brought it down.
After much struggling, the foreman of the crew came to the
rescue of his crewmen, driving
stenographer
disgruntled
the
from the field. At last report, she
is no longer speaking to her boy

friend, who was standing nearby
and did- nothing to help her.
None of the crewmen involved
had any comments on the situation, but several undergraduates
commented on the appropriateness of the standard. Neither the
Plant Manager nor any of those
present could suggest the name
or names of the perpetrators of
the stunt, though presumably
they are undergraduates.
The stunt is vaguely reminiscent of the red lantern hung
from Gilman Tower last year.
Evidently some agility was used,
for the rope on the flag was cut
off quite close to the top of the
pole.

'Team Balanced'
In commenting about the varsity, Coach Hartman said, "We
don't have any real stars on the
team, but we have a lot of balance. The over-all team will do
well in the Mason-Dixon Conference.
"Pete Hubbard has got an unusually good backhand, but his
service and forehand are not
as good. His game is better than
average now, and, since he's
only a sophomore, he should
develop into a good tennis player. I think that Don Squair can
play a lot better tennis than he
has been, and I expect him to
improve."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 25, 1958

Eisenhower Repeats Attack News-Letter Seeks
On Schools In L. A. Speech To Retain Freedom
Dr. Milton Eisenhower, speaking before the Advertising Council in Los Angeles, California,
this week, again stated the need
for revision of American education at all levels.
He acknowledged that, "with
perspective, .. . the American
system of mass education is the
greatest and most efficient ever
devised and maintained by any
society."
Still, he maintained, a problem is now present, and he defined this problem as partly "a
quantitative one." Also, "the
quality of teaching is unfortunately on a toboggan. Thousands
of teachers with inferior preparation are in our elementary and
secondary schools, and at the
higher levels the percentage of
new teachers who have the Ph.D.
is each year declining.
Reduction In Quality
"This reduction in quality,
caused by a tremendous upsurge
in student numbers, is occurring
at a time when we already have
a serious qualitative problem on
our hands."
Dr. Eisenhower again proposed
his remedies for this problem. He
stated that "we must improve
the quality of the entire educational program. ... One obvious
reason why this is so, is this:
most students ... do not decide
upon areas of specialization until
they are well advanced in their
collegiate studies."
Requires Preparations
"In other words," he continued,
"wise ultimate choice requires
sound preparation which is essentially common to all fields of
specialization. It also calls for
a degree of maturity, experience,
and an informed judgment with
respect to available choices. .. .
Patently, this improvement must
begin with the elementary and
secondary schools."
Dr. Eisenhower mentioned that
the secondary schools in partic-

ular fail to prepare capable students adequately. He stated that
many students capable of academic accomplishment "are not
receiving their due. Our secondary schools, in response to
public pressures, have tended to
proliferate themselves into decreased quality. Our secondary
schools, collectively, now offer
choices in several hundred different subjects, many of them
vocational. There is no substitute,
in preparatory education, for
rigorous study of such fundamentals as mathematics, English, a foreign language, science,
history and social studies.
Not Opposed
"I•am not opposed to classes
in driver-training, typing, stenography, woodworking, cooking, social dancing, industrial
processes, and the like, except
when they are substituted for
sound intellectual development.
Since hours of instruction are
limited ,this is what too often
happens. I would therefore remove all peripheral subjects
from the curriculums of those
who are capable of pursuing the
more rigorous academic subjects,
and concentrate these subjects in
a thirteenth high school year for
those who want terminal vocational education."
Continuing, Dr. Eisenhower
stated that he "would increase
the academic load of all capable students. We are too casual
about education. This is the primary reason why European students achieve scholastically in
ten years what ours do in
twelve—and it happens that
most students do better work
with a heavy load than a light
one. I would then sectionalize all
classes, so that every student is
constantly challenged intellectually in the educational process."
Must Increase Quality
The Hopkins president recommended further reforms, saying
that "we must increase the qual-

JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, APRIL 25, 1958

VOL. LXII, NO. 24

4E000

62ND YEAR

Ike, Macmillan To View Graduation,
Speak To University AssemblyIn June

HAROLD MACMILLAN

British Prime Minister Harold 'Macmillan and Dwight
D. Eisenhower, President of the United States, will attend
the commencement exercises at Hopkins on Tuesday,
June 10.
White House Press Secretary James Haggerty also
announced that Macmillan will deliver the principal address at the ceremonies. Macmillan is scheduled to receive
an honorary degree from the University.
Macmillan will be in the United States to confer with
the President and other U.S. leaders.
The Prime Minister is expected to arrive in the
United States on June 7 and will first speak at graduation
exercises at DePaul University, in Greencastle, Indiana, his
mother's home state, on June 8.
The original invitation to Mr. Macmillan to address
the graduating Hopkins students was extended personally
by Dr. Milton Eisenhower, president of Hopkins and the
brother of the President. His acceptance was received at
the White House a week ago.
The Prime Minister, the son of an English father
and an American mother, accepted his ilost January 10,
1957, at a time when a rift was appearing between England
and the U.S. over the former's policy toward Egypt.
He is generally considered to have been a major force
in helping to repair Anglo-American relations.
Macmillan, a personal friend of the President since
1942, met Eisenhower as the British Cabinet's political representative at Eisenhower's wartime headquarters in Africa.
When Eden became Prime Minister in 1955, he named
Macmillan to succeed him as Secretary of State for Foreign
Affairs. Eight months later Macmillan took over England's
finances by becoming Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Macmillan will be making his fifth visit to the U.S.
in the past three years. His most recent appearance in
Washington last October led to a joint statement with
President Eisenhower of a "declaration of common purpose" between the United States and Britain.

Valediction
This issue marks the final chapter in the book of
Baroway and Kahler. Next week Turnbull and Figinski
will assume the role of the household lords, and may the
gods that be go with them. We two have made some discoveries about this campus within the past year. For
one, history repeats itself: in perusing past News-Letters
and conversing with past editors we learned, and it was
no surprise, that as far back as the '20's editors were
feuding with the Student Council and various other student
organizations, dormitory food provoked riots, this paper
was looked upon as a scandal sheet, fraternity drinking
was then a problem, and everybody and his brother
looked upon campus dilemmas with severity and regarded
them as very important.
We have also discovered that these problems, which
may appear to us in later years to be but petty foibles,
should be important to us.now. As important as hydrogen
bombs, or recessions, or national politics. For this is our
little world, yours and ours. We live here. We feed upon
its fruits, and we die a thousand deaths when' some
monkey wrench gets flung into it.

--Correspondence
To the Editors!
We read with interest the
News-Letter article of April 18
about the enlargement of the
Student Council to include the
editor of the News-Letter and the
Cotillion Board President. Undoubtedly, the Student Council
Will be a more effective organization with these new representatives, and in the future there
Will be less conflict among campus organizations.
However, we were very sorry
to see that the enlargement
stopped where it did. It seems
to us that if the News-Letter
is represented, then WJHU, the
campus radio station, should be
also; if the Cotillion Board, then
the 'Y' Cabinet. The Engineering Control Board certainly deserves a place on the SC, but an
Arts and Sciences Control Board
and a Business Control Board
should be created to represent
these students too. Last year's
admission of the IFB President
Should be followed by the creation of an officer to represent
the GDI's, and perhaps the Baltimore students need a vote to
balance the DSRC's vote.
Since the Deans and Chairmen of all the departments will
find the new SC a perfect place
for dealing with the student

Pirates Hang 'Jolly Roger'
From University Mainmast
A black flag, described by observers as a "Jolly Roger," was
removed from the flagpole near
Homewood House with considerable difficulty. A crew from the
Plant Manager's Office produced
one intrepid volunteer who, after
several slips and false starts,
succeeded in removing the object.
An unidentified secretary attempted to wrest the flag from
the man who brought it down.
After much struggling, the foreman of the crew came to the
rescue of his crewmen, driving
stenographer
disgruntled
the
from the field. At last report, she
is no longer speaking to her boy

friend, who was standing nearby
and did- nothing to help her.
None of the crewmen involved
had any comments on the situation, but several undergraduates
commented on the appropriateness of the standard. Neither the
Plant Manager nor any of those
present could suggest the name
or names of the perpetrators of
the stunt, though presumably
they are undergraduates.
The stunt is vaguely reminiscent of the red lantern hung
from Gilman Tower last year.
Evidently some agility was used,
for the rope on the flag was cut
off quite close to the top of the
pole.

Eight Marks Fall
In Track Event
In BIA Meets
The finals of the intramural
track meet, held last Friday, saw
8 records fall and one tied as
the Frosh trackmen topped the
14 team field with 42 points.
The individual high point men
were Jorge Diez De Onate of the
frosh with 13 points and ZBT's
Chuck Green with 12.
The 220 was Onate's only first.
while Green won the shotput,
beating the old record set by
Dale Steward in 1956 of 38' with
a 39'10" effort, and the broad
jump with a leap of 18'6".
Records continued to fall as
Kurt Ries of Beta took the 120
high hurdles with a time of 19:0
bettering the old record set in
1957 by Bill Berndt of 19:2, and
the 220 low hurdles in 29:0 bettering the previous mark of 29:4
set by Tom Engler in 1956.
Records Broken
Don Smilovitz of the frosh
chipped in with two records,
breaking the existing 880 record
set in 1956 by Gene Harshman
of 2:12 with a 2:10:.1 effort, and
the mile record also set in 1956
by Morris Jones of 4:57 with a
time of 4:56:9.
The 440, Skip Shields romped
home in 56:4 to break Bruce
Wood's 1956 record of 57 seconds.'
while Ed Von Gehren of AD tied

11:27:5.

Bates, and Vic Dates broke Phi
Gam's record of 1:44:8 with a
mark of 1:41:9.

The Johns Hopkins varsity

The Blue Jays
won their first
home meet last Saturday, as they
beat Western Maryland 78 1/3
to 43 2/3, taking ten first places

Caples taking the 120 yard high

team prepared this week to face

. Frosh Prepare
Following tomorrow's meet, the
Jays will face Delaware and
Loyola at home and Dickinson
away.

compiled a 1-1 record thus far,
losing to Mt. St. Joe before
bouncing back to defeat Poly B,
70-43. Following the Delaware
meet, the frosh will close the
season against Bainbridge Prep
on Friday, May 9.

arid Luis Bartolomei, thild in
the low hurdles.

with Jerry Cohen taking the

arid Ron Clark and Gus Colon
taking second and third. Colon
won the high jump clearing 5'8".

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, APRIL 25, 1958

Eisenhower Repeats Attack News-Letter Seeks
On Schools In L. A. Speech To Retain Freedom
Dr. Milton Eisenhower, speaking before the Advertising Council in Los Angeles, California,
this week, again stated the need
for revision of American education at all levels.
He acknowledged that, "with
perspective, .. . the American
system of mass education is the
greatest and most efficient ever
devised and maintained by any
society."
Still, he maintained, a problem is now present, and he defined this problem as partly "a
quantitative one." Also, "the
quality of teaching is unfortunately on a toboggan. Thousands
of teachers with inferior preparation are in our elementary and
secondary schools, and at the
higher levels the percentage of
new teachers who have the Ph.D.
is each year declining.
Reduction In Quality
"This reduction in quality,
caused by a tremendous upsurge
in student numbers, is occurring
at a time when we already have
a serious qualitative problem on
our hands."
Dr. Eisenhower again proposed
his remedies for this problem. He
stated that "we must improve
the quality of the entire educational program. ... One obvious
reason why this is so, is this:
most students ... do not decide
upon areas of specialization until
they are well advanced in their
collegiate studies."
Requires Preparations
"In other words," he continued,
"wise ultimate choice requires
sound preparation which is essentially common to all fields of
specialization. It also calls for
a degree of maturity, experience,
and an informed judgment with
respect to available choices. .. .
Patently, this improvement must
begin with the elementary and
secondary schools."
Dr. Eisenhower mentioned that
the secondary schools in partic-

ular fail to prepare capable students adequately. He stated that
many students capable of academic accomplishment "are not
receiving their due. Our secondary schools, in response to
public pressures, have tended to
proliferate themselves into decreased quality. Our secondary
schools, collectively, now offer
choices in several hundred different subjects, many of them
vocational. There is no substitute,
in preparatory education, for
rigorous study of such fundamentals as mathematics, English, a foreign language, science,
history and social studies.
Not Opposed
"I•am not opposed to classes
in driver-training, typing, stenography, woodworking, cooking, social dancing, industrial
processes, and the like, except
when they are substituted for
sound intellectual development.
Since hours of instruction are
limited ,this is what too often
happens. I would therefore remove all peripheral subjects
from the curriculums of those
who are capable of pursuing the
more rigorous academic subjects,
and concentrate these subjects in
a thirteenth high school year for
those who want terminal vocational education."
Continuing, Dr. Eisenhower
stated that he "would increase
the academic load of all capable students. We are too casual
about education. This is the primary reason why European students achieve scholastically in
ten years what ours do in
twelve—and it happens that
most students do better work
with a heavy load than a light
one. I would then sectionalize all
classes, so that every student is
constantly challenged intellectually in the educational process."
Must Increase Quality
The Hopkins president recommended further reforms, saying
that "we must increase the qual-
